title: 108_hr1079
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the Short Title. It includes Increased Expensing for Small Business. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" includes an amendment to the dollar limitation under section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, increasing the threshold to $75,000 for the aggregate cost that can be taken into account for any taxable year. Additionally, there is an increase in the phaseout threshold for the reduction in limitation. The amendment to section 179 of the Internal Revenue Code increases the phaseout threshold from $200,000 to $325,000. The definition of section 179 property now includes tangible property under section 168. The term 'section 179 property' includes tangible property under section 168, computer software as defined in section 197(e)(3)(B), and section 1245 property acquired by purchase for use. The term 'section 179 property' includes tangible property under section 168, computer software, and section 1245 property acquired for use in a trade or business. This term excludes property described in section 50(b), air conditioning, and heating units. Inflation adjustments are made to the dollar limitation and phaseout threshold in section 179 of the Code. Inflation adjustments are made to the dollar limitation and phaseout threshold in section 179 of the Code for taxable years after 2003. The dollar limitation in section 179 of the Code is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, starting from 2002. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $1,000, it is rounded accordingly. The dollar limitation in section 179 of the Code is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, starting from 2002. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $1,000, it is rounded accordingly to the nearest multiple of $1,000. If the phaseout amount is not a multiple of $10,000, it is rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. The taxpayer can revoke an election under paragraph (1) of section 179(c) of the Code with respect to any property, and once revoked, it is irrevocable. The amendments made by this section have an effective date. The taxpayer can revoke an election under paragraph (1) of section 179(c) of the Code with respect to any property, and once revoked, it is irrevocable. The amendments made by this section have an effective date of taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Neutral cost recovery depreciation adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. Deduction adjustment to allow equivalent of expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003 under Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. To fully expense property under section 179, the deduction is adjusted by substituting '150 percent' for '200 percent' in subsection (b)(1) for certain property. The deduction amount for subsequent taxable years is determined accordingly. The deduction amount for subsequent taxable years is determined by multiplying the amount determined under section 179 for the taxable year by the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property in a taxable year is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the corresponding calendar quarter. The gross domestic product deflator for the calendar quarter ending in the taxable year is multiplied by the deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the taxpayer. The deflator for the calendar quarter when the property was placed in service by the taxpayer is multiplied by 1.035 to the nth power, where 'n' is the number of full years from the quarter of placement to the day before. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service by the taxpayer is calculated based on the number of full years in the period, rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio must not be less than 1 and is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. Special rules apply for certain types of property, and the gross domestic product deflator is used for calculations. The gross domestic product deflator is used for calculations in certain property situations. Taxpayers can elect not to have this subsection apply, and once the election is made, it is irrevocable. This subsection does not apply to property in churning transactions. Taxpayers can elect not to have this subsection apply to their property, and once the election is made, it is irrevocable. This subsection does not apply to property in churning transactions. The additional deduction under this section does not affect the adjusted basis of property or interests in pass-thru entities holding the property. It is also not considered a depreciation deduction for sections 1245 and 1250. The term 'pass-thru entity' includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds for purposes of depreciation deductions under sections 1245 and 1250. Minimum tax treatment under section 56(a) of the Code is amended. Minimum Tax Treatment is amended under section 56(a) of the Code for pass-thru entities including partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. The amendment allows for the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property subject to section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003. The deduction allowable for property subject to section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003, is determined by multiplying the allowable amount for the taxable year by the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio. The neutral cost recovery deduction for property subject to section 168(k) is determined by multiplying the allowable amount for the taxable year by the applicable ratio. This deduction does not apply to property with an election in effect to not have section 168(k) apply. The neutral cost recovery deduction under section 168(k) does not apply to certain automobiles subject to depreciation limitations in the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2003, regarding the coordination with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles.
